elements.content: Four helical copper complexes Cu­[N­(CN)2]2­(Hhmp) (1), {Cu­[N­(CN)2]2­(Hhmp)}∞ (2), (l-{Cu4[N­(CN)2]2­(hmp)4­(CH3COO)2·​CH3CN}∞ (3a), and d-{Cu4[N­(CN)2]2­(hmp)4­(CH3COO)2·​CH3CN}∞ (3b) (Hhmp = 2-(hydroxy­methyl)­pyridine) have been prepared toward a mimic DNA structure. By changing the solvent and supplementary ligand, the structures can be successfully tuned from quasi-double-helical (complex 1) to racemic 1D single helix (complex 2), then the right (3a)-/left (3b)-handed double helices. The topologies of 3a and 3b may be considered as a mimic of DNA, where the Cu–O bonds between the two strands replace the hydrogen-bonding interactions in DNA. Solid-state circular dichroism spectra confirmed that 3a and 3b are optically active, respectively. Magnetic measurements for 1–3 indicated all complexes to be antiferromagnetic interactions. The best fitting results to the magnetic susceptibilities were J = −0.80 cm–1, g = 2.11 for 1 and J 1 = −9.22 cm–1, J 2 = 3.56 cm–1, J 3 = −9.49 cm–1, g = 2.27 for 3.
elements.clean_text: Four helical copper complexes Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp) (1), {Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp)}∞ (2), (l-{Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3a), and d-{Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3b) (Hhmp = 2-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) have been prepared toward a mimic DNA structure. By changing the solvent and supplementary ligand, the structures can be successfully tuned from quasi-double-helical (complex 1) to racemic 1D single helix (complex 2), then the right (3a)-/left (3b)-handed double helices. The topologies of 3a and 3b may be considered as a mimic of DNA, where the Cu-O bonds between the two strands replace the hydrogen-bonding interactions in DNA. Solid-state circular dichroism spectra confirmed that 3a and 3b are optically active, respectively. Magnetic measurements for 1-3 indicated all complexes to be antiferromagnetic interactions. The best fitting results to the magnetic susceptibilities were J = -0.80 cm-1, g = 2.11 for 1 and J 1 = -9.22 cm-1, J 2 = 3.56 cm-1, J 3 = -9.49 cm-1, g = 2.27 for 3.

elements.content: By changing the solvent and supplementary ligand, the structures based on achiral building blocks can be successfully tuned from quasi-double-helical (complex 1) to racemic 1D single helix (complex 2), then the right (3a)-/left (3b)-handed double helices. The topologies of 3a and 3b can be regarded as a mimic of DNA.
elements.clean_text: By changing the solvent and supplementary ligand, the structures based on achiral building blocks can be successfully tuned from quasi-double-helical (complex 1) to racemic 1D single helix (complex 2), then the right (3a)-/left (3b)-handed double helices. The topologies of 3a and 3b can be regarded as a mimic of DNA.

elements.content: The construction of multifunctional materials is the current interest for both chemists and physicists. Recently, magnetic materials with chiral structures have attracted considerable attention in molecular materials, since such materials may combine optical activity with various magnetic properties and have relevance to understanding the origin of asymmetry in life. Although a few chiral structured magnets have been reported until now, the exploration for how to control the absolute conformation of chirality in a molecular structure to acquire enantiopure chiral structured magnets is still an appealing challenge. There are two strategies for the designing and construction of enantiotopic molecular magnets: (1) the utilization of enantiopure ligands and (2) spontaneous resolution starting from achiral precursors. For the first strategy, it needs high cost and the types of enantiopure ligands are limited. For the second strategy, the chirality is derived from the spatial arrangement of achiral building blocks and the achiral ligands are more common, which is more promising.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The construction of multifunctional materials is the current interest for both chemists and physicists. Recently, magnetic materials with chiral structures have attracted considerable attention in molecular materials, since such materials may combine optical activity with various magnetic properties and have relevance to understanding the origin of asymmetry in life. Although a few chiral structured magnets have been reported until now, the exploration for how to control the absolute conformation of chirality in a molecular structure to acquire enantiopure chiral structured magnets is still an appealing challenge. There are two strategies for the designing and construction of enantiotopic molecular magnets: (1) the utilization of enantiopure ligands and (2) spontaneous resolution starting from achiral precursors. For the first strategy, it needs high cost and the types of enantiopure ligands are limited. For the second strategy, the chirality is derived from the spatial arrangement of achiral building blocks and the achiral ligands are more common, which is more promising.

elements.content: Helicity, being one important origin of chirality, is ubiquitous in nature and our life, such as the protein single helices and the DNA double helix, which play a crucial role in pharmacology and the life sciences, etc. Such helical structures, which usually consist of discrete oligonuclear helicates or one-dimensional (1D) helical chains, can be assembled with enantiopure, racemic or achiral molecules as building blocks and show left- and/or right-handed forms. In general, when using enantiopure chiral molecules as building blocks, the helical compounds exhibit homochiral features. Without any chiral source, helices are usually produced with helical conformations spontaneously; that is, they tend to be racemic with an equal distribution of left- and right-helices. So far, a few examples of 3D open-framework materials and 1D helical chain complexes, in some rare cases, have been synthesized to be homochiral by spontaneous resolution. However, it has not been very well understood how to induce enantiopure chiral packing of helical chains in crystals in the absence of chiral precursors. Therefore, if the helicity of the helical structures could be selectively prepared in one conformation for the entire crystal structure on a supramolecular level, it will lead to the homochiral helices for efficient chiral recognition processes and help us to realize the origin of the helicity of biopolymers.
elements.clean_text: Helicity, being one important origin of chirality, is ubiquitous in nature and our life, such as the protein single helices and the DNA double helix, which play a crucial role in pharmacology and the life sciences, etc. Such helical structures, which usually consist of discrete oligonuclear helicates or one-dimensional (1D) helical chains, can be assembled with enantiopure, racemic or achiral molecules as building blocks and show left- and/or right-handed forms. In general, when using enantiopure chiral molecules as building blocks, the helical compounds exhibit homochiral features. Without any chiral source, helices are usually produced with helical conformations spontaneously; that is, they tend to be racemic with an equal distribution of left- and right-helices. So far, a few examples of 3D open-framework materials and 1D helical chain complexes, in some rare cases, have been synthesized to be homochiral by spontaneous resolution. However, it has not been very well understood how to induce enantiopure chiral packing of helical chains in crystals in the absence of chiral precursors. Therefore, if the helicity of the helical structures could be selectively prepared in one conformation for the entire crystal structure on a supramolecular level, it will lead to the homochiral helices for efficient chiral recognition processes and help us to realize the origin of the helicity of biopolymers.

elements.content: The previous reports have demonstrated that a flexible bridging ligand supports the formation of helical structures, and the chelated aromatic ligands, blocking some coordination sites of metal ions, often prevent generating extended networks. Inspired by these achievements, we have chosen dicyanamido (dca, N­(CN)2 –, a), 2-(hydroxy­methyl)­pyridine (Hhmp, b), and transition-metal copper­(II) as starting materials to tune the configuration of the target products. When these materials are incorporated, the obtained materials may exhibit magnetic, helical, and possible multifunctionality. As expected, we have successfully prepared four novel CuII complexes (Cu­[N­(CN)2]2­(Hhmp) (1), {Cu­[N­(CN)2]2­(Hhmp)}∞ (2), l-{Cu4[N­(CN)2]2­(hmp)4­(CH3COO)2·​CH3CN}∞ (3a), and d-{Cu4[N­(CN)2]2­(hmp)4­(CH3COO)2·​CH3CN}∞ (3b)) with a 1D helical structure.
elements.clean_text: The previous reports have demonstrated that a flexible bridging ligand supports the formation of helical structures, and the chelated aromatic ligands, blocking some coordination sites of metal ions, often prevent generating extended networks. Inspired by these achievements, we have chosen dicyanamido (dca, N(CN)2 -, a), 2-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine (Hhmp, b), and transition-metal copper(II) as starting materials to tune the configuration of the target products. When these materials are incorporated, the obtained materials may exhibit magnetic, helical, and possible multifunctionality. As expected, we have successfully prepared four novel CuII complexes (Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp) (1), {Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp)}∞ (2), l-{Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3a), and d-{Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3b)) with a 1D helical structure.

elements.content: In this work, we describe for the first time the rational designing toward a mimic DNA structure and synthesis process of a series of unique compounds 1–3 () based on achiral building blocks from achirality to chirality by molecular manipulation. As shown in , we first obtained compound 1 by the reaction of Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O, Hhmp, NaN­(CN)2, and triethylamine in water. The formation of the novel quasi-double-helical structure for 1 is assisted by the strong hydrogen-bonding interactions as well as the flexible bridging ligand dca. Then, by changing the solvent (using CH3CN/H2O instead of H2O), the strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are eliminated and genuine 1D helical structures of single helix (compound 2) are acquired. However, it is racemic. Based on these, 3a and 3b are spontaneously self-assembled into homochiral double-helical chains for the entire crystal by changing the solvent CH3CN/H2O into CH3CN/CH3OH and a supplementary ligand (CH3COO–). Compounds 3a and 3b are enantiomers as well as a right-/left-handed double-helical metal complex linked via Hhmp ligands coordinating to Cu2+ ions. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of 3a and 3b indicate that the crystals are optically active. The topologies of 3a and 3b may be considered as analogues of DNA, where Cu–O bonds between the two strands replace the hydrogen-bonding interactions. In fact, helical-chain complexes containing such an arrangement with a topology of DNA are extremely rare and only one example stimulated by an ionic liquid anion has been reported, where the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the two strands were substituted by Mn–O coordinations. The magnetic properties of 1–3 have also been studied.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we describe for the first time the rational designing toward a mimic DNA structure and synthesis process of a series of unique compounds 1-3 () based on achiral building blocks from achirality to chirality by molecular manipulation. As shown in , we first obtained compound 1 by the reaction of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, Hhmp, NaN(CN)2, and triethylamine in water. The formation of the novel quasi-double-helical structure for 1 is assisted by the strong hydrogen-bonding interactions as well as the flexible bridging ligand dca. Then, by changing the solvent (using CH3CN/H2O instead of H2O), the strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are eliminated and genuine 1D helical structures of single helix (compound 2) are acquired. However, it is racemic. Based on these, 3a and 3b are spontaneously self-assembled into homochiral double-helical chains for the entire crystal by changing the solvent CH3CN/H2O into CH3CN/CH3OH and a supplementary ligand (CH3COO-). Compounds 3a and 3b are enantiomers as well as a right-/left-handed double-helical metal complex linked via Hhmp ligands coordinating to Cu2+ ions. The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of 3a and 3b indicate that the crystals are optically active. The topologies of 3a and 3b may be considered as analogues of DNA, where Cu-O bonds between the two strands replace the hydrogen-bonding interactions. In fact, helical-chain complexes containing such an arrangement with a topology of DNA are extremely rare and only one example stimulated by an ionic liquid anion has been reported, where the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the two strands were substituted by Mn-O coordinations. The magnetic properties of 1-3 have also been studied.

elements.content: Rational modulation from achirality to chirality (compounds 1–3) following a successful strategy without any chiral source.
elements.clean_text: 1  Rational modulation from achirality to chirality (compounds 1-3) following a successful strategy without any chiral source.

elements.content:
All preparations were performed under aerobic conditions; all the reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of Cu­[N­(CN)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(Hhmp) (<bold>1</bold>)

To a stirred solution of Hhmp (0.2181 g, 2 mmol) and triethylamine (2 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added NaC­(CN)2 (0.1781 g, 2 mmol). Then, Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.741 g, 2 mmol) was added to the solution. After stirring for 2 h, the color of the solution changed to blue. The resulting solution was filtered, and the filtrate was then kept at room temperature for slow evaporation. After a few days, blue crystals were obtained. Yield: 75% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7­N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.19; N, 32.26.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Syntheses

All preparations were performed under aerobic conditions; all the reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp) (1)

To a stirred solution of Hhmp (0.2181 g, 2 mmol) and triethylamine (2 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added NaC(CN)2 (0.1781 g, 2 mmol). Then, Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.741 g, 2 mmol) was added to the solution. After stirring for 2 h, the color of the solution changed to blue. The resulting solution was filtered, and the filtrate was then kept at room temperature for slow evaporation. After a few days, blue crystals were obtained. Yield: 75% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.19; N, 32.26.

elements.content: Complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as 1 except for using CH3CN/H2O (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) instead of H2O. Yield: 60% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7­N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.31; H, 2.45; N, 32.03.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp)}∞ (2)

Complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as 1 except for using CH3CN/H2O (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) instead of H2O. Yield: 60% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.31; H, 2.45; N, 32.03.

elements.content: Complex 3 was prepared in the same manner as 2 except that Cu­(CH3COO)2 (0.3992 g, 2 mmol) and CH3CN/CH3OH (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) were used instead of Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O and CH3CN/H2O, respectively. Yield: 50% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C34H33­N11O8Cu4 (977.91): C, 41.76; H, 3.40; N, 15.76. Found: C, 41.85; H, 3.33; N, 15.65.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3)

Complex 3 was prepared in the same manner as 2 except that Cu(CH3COO)2 (0.3992 g, 2 mmol) and CH3CN/CH3OH (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) were used instead of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and CH3CN/H2O, respectively. Yield: 50% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C34H33N11O8Cu4 (977.91): C, 41.76; H, 3.40; N, 15.76. Found: C, 41.85; H, 3.33; N, 15.65.

elements.content: Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) in the range of 3–35° at room temperature. DC magnetic susceptibilities were measured using Quantum Design MPMSXL-5 SQUID instruments. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal’s constants). The CD spectra were measured on a JASCO Corp., J-810 spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) in the range of 3-35° at room temperature. DC magnetic susceptibilities were measured using Quantum Design MPMSXL-5 SQUID instruments. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal's constants). The CD spectra were measured on a JASCO Corp., J-810 spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data sets of complexes 1–3 were obtained on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra detector diffractometer using the graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Intense data were collected by the ω scan technique. The diffraction patterns for complexes were indexed using CrysAlis software to obtain the unit cell parameters. The structures were solved with the direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystallographic data and structure refinement details are collected in . Selected bond lengths for 1–3 are listed in Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray data sets of complexes 1-3 were obtained on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini R Ultra detector diffractometer using the graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Intense data were collected by the ω scan technique. The diffraction patterns for complexes were indexed using CrysAlis software to obtain the unit cell parameters. The structures were solved with the direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The crystallographic data and structure refinement details are collected in . Selected bond lengths for 1-3 are listed in Table S2.

wR 2 = [∑w(|F o|2 – |F c|2)2/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

Compounds 1–3 were prepared following a three-step strategy. The reaction of Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O, Hhmp, NaN­(CN)2, and triethylamine (molar ratio 1:1:1:1) in water at room temperature afforded blue block crystals of 1. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in a, there is only one crystallographically independent CuII ion in the asymmetric unit. The Cu1 ion is five coordinated, adopting a slightly distorted CuNO4 square-pyramidal geometry with τ = 0.25. The basal plane is occupied by two N atoms from two dca ligands, and one O atom and one N atom from the Hhmp ligand. The bond lengths in the basal plane vary from 1.965 to 1.993 Å. The apical sites are occupied by one N atom from the dca ligand, with Cu1–N5 bond lengths of 2.316(3) Å (Table S2). Two neighboring Cu ions are first connected by two μ2-1,5-dca ligands to generate a dinuclear Cu­(II) cluster structure with a Cu···Cu distance of 7.318(1) Å (b), and then the dinuclear clusters are joined together through O–H···N hydrogen bonds to form a unique 1D quasi-double-helical chain (see c). The helical chains in the hydrogen-bonded quasi-double-helix share CuII ions at each turn of two helical chains and have opposite handedness.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Compounds 1-3 were prepared following a three-step strategy. The reaction of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, Hhmp, NaN(CN)2, and triethylamine (molar ratio 1:1:1:1) in water at room temperature afforded blue block crystals of 1. Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As depicted in a, there is only one crystallographically independent CuII ion in the asymmetric unit. The Cu1 ion is five coordinated, adopting a slightly distorted CuNO4 square-pyramidal geometry with τ = 0.25. The basal plane is occupied by two N atoms from two dca ligands, and one O atom and one N atom from the Hhmp ligand. The bond lengths in the basal plane vary from 1.965 to 1.993 Å. The apical sites are occupied by one N atom from the dca ligand, with Cu1-N5 bond lengths of 2.316(3) Å (Table S2). Two neighboring Cu ions are first connected by two μ2-1,5-dca ligands to generate a dinuclear Cu(II) cluster structure with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 7.318(1) Å (b), and then the dinuclear clusters are joined together through O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds to form a unique 1D quasi-double-helical chain (see c). The helical chains in the hydrogen-bonded quasi-double-helix share CuII ions at each turn of two helical chains and have opposite handedness.

elements.content: Structure of compound 1: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) The dinuclear Cu­(II) cluster connected by two μ2-1,5-dca ligands. (c) The double-helical chain with the left one drawn in green and the right one drawn in pink. The dashed ones represent the hydrogen bonds (O–H···N).
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure of compound 1: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) The dinuclear Cu(II) cluster connected by two μ2-1,5-dca ligands. (c) The double-helical chain with the left one drawn in green and the right one drawn in pink. The dashed ones represent the hydrogen bonds (O-H⋅⋅⋅N).

elements.content: It is worth noting that the Hhmp ligands in complex 1, those chelate Cu ions alternately at two sides of the chain, are protonated, although triethylamine was added into the reaction solution as starting material. Therefore, the additional μ-dca ligands behave as connectors linking the neighboring two dinuclear Cu­(II) clusters through O–H···N hydrogen bonds. Consequently, a 1D quasi-double-helical chain is formed as expected. During this process, the use of a flexible bridging ligand (dca) and a chelated aromatic ligand (Hhmp) undoubtedly steers the formation of the helicates. Indeed, this observation has been already reported for similar ligands. Inspection of the structure of compound 1 suggests that it is possible to separate the quasi-double-helical chain, forming single helical chains by changing reaction conditions. When the polarity of solvent was reduced by introducing CH3CN to H2O, although the Hhmp ligands were still protonated, compound 2 with a different 1D single-helical chain structure was isolated without hydrogen bonds. The asymmetric unit of 2 is similar to 1 but exhibits some differences in structural parameters. The bond lengths in the basal plane are in the 1.945–2.002 Å range, which are listed in Table S2. The Cu1–N2 bond length in the apical direction is 2.239(3) Å. As a consequence of the differences, compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Unlike compound 1, the CuII ions in compound 2 are connected alternately by μ2-1,5-dca ligands to form the single helical −(Cu-N-C-N-C-N) n – chains running along the screw axis. Notably, there are two types of helical copper chains in compound 2, one featuring left-handedness and the other featuring right-handedness (b). The adjacent opposite-handedness helical copper chains were parallel to each other, resulting in the entire crystal structure of compound 2 being racemic.
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that the Hhmp ligands in complex 1, those chelate Cu ions alternately at two sides of the chain, are protonated, although triethylamine was added into the reaction solution as starting material. Therefore, the additional μ-dca ligands behave as connectors linking the neighboring two dinuclear Cu(II) clusters through O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds. Consequently, a 1D quasi-double-helical chain is formed as expected. During this process, the use of a flexible bridging ligand (dca) and a chelated aromatic ligand (Hhmp) undoubtedly steers the formation of the helicates. Indeed, this observation has been already reported for similar ligands. Inspection of the structure of compound 1 suggests that it is possible to separate the quasi-double-helical chain, forming single helical chains by changing reaction conditions. When the polarity of solvent was reduced by introducing CH3CN to H2O, although the Hhmp ligands were still protonated, compound 2 with a different 1D single-helical chain structure was isolated without hydrogen bonds. The asymmetric unit of 2 is similar to 1 but exhibits some differences in structural parameters. The bond lengths in the basal plane are in the 1.945-2.002 Å range, which are listed in Table S2. The Cu1-N2 bond length in the apical direction is 2.239(3) Å. As a consequence of the differences, compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Unlike compound 1, the CuII ions in compound 2 are connected alternately by μ2-1,5-dca ligands to form the single helical -(Cu-N-C-N-C-N) n - chains running along the screw axis. Notably, there are two types of helical copper chains in compound 2, one featuring left-handedness and the other featuring right-handedness (b). The adjacent opposite-handedness helical copper chains were parallel to each other, resulting in the entire crystal structure of compound 2 being racemic.

elements.content: Structure of compound 2: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) The left- and right-handed helical chains.
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of compound 2: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) The left- and right-handed helical chains.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 or 2 only contains one crystallographically independent CuII ion. For complex 2, the dca ligands link the CuII ions one by one, then forming a 1D single helical chain, whereas, for complex 1, two dca ligands connect two crystallographically independent CuII ions to form a dinuclear cluster, and then, under the help of hydrogen-bonding interactions, 1 shows a 1D quasi-double-helical chain structure. If the Hhmp ligands are deprotonated, the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the additional dca ligands and the Hhmp ligands can be destroyed and the additional dca ligands could bond with high-nuclear metal clusters, in an appropriate mode, which provides 1D double-helical/multihelical complexes. In our previously report, we have found that the Hhmp ligand could be deprotonated by triethylamine in CH3CN/CH3OH, and the auxiliary ligand CH3COO– favors the formation of [Cu4O4] cubane. Therefore, using Cu­(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu­(ClO4)2 and changing the solvent into CH3CN/CH3OH compared with 1 and 2, compound 3 consisting of double-helical chains was prepared successfully by spontaneous resolution.
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit of 1 or 2 only contains one crystallographically independent CuII ion. For complex 2, the dca ligands link the CuII ions one by one, then forming a 1D single helical chain, whereas, for complex 1, two dca ligands connect two crystallographically independent CuII ions to form a dinuclear cluster, and then, under the help of hydrogen-bonding interactions, 1 shows a 1D quasi-double-helical chain structure. If the Hhmp ligands are deprotonated, the hydrogen-bonding interactions between the additional dca ligands and the Hhmp ligands can be destroyed and the additional dca ligands could bond with high-nuclear metal clusters, in an appropriate mode, which provides 1D double-helical/multihelical complexes. In our previously report, we have found that the Hhmp ligand could be deprotonated by triethylamine in CH3CN/CH3OH, and the auxiliary ligand CH3COO- favors the formation of [Cu4O4] cubane. Therefore, using Cu(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu(ClO4)2 and changing the solvent into CH3CN/CH3OH compared with 1 and 2, compound 3 consisting of double-helical chains was prepared successfully by spontaneous resolution.

elements.content: Both 3a and 3b crystallize in the chiral monoclinic space group P21. The Flack parameters of 0.022(17) (3a) and −0.021(12) (3b) indicate the homochirality of the crystal. Compared with 1 and 2, the asymmetric unit of 3 consists of four Cu­(II) ions, two N­(CN)2 – anions, four hmp– anions, two CH3COO– anions, and one uncoordinated CH3CN molecule. Compounds 3a and 3b are enantiomers, and only 3a is discussed as examples below. As shown in a, each Cu­(II) ion in the asymmetric unit is hexacoordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry. Each CuII is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from one hmp– ligand and one N­(CN)2 – anion, three oxygen atoms from three hmp– ligands, and one carboxylate oxygen atom. There are four μ3-O atoms from four hmp– ligands, which connect four Cu cations to form a [Cu4O4] cubane. The chirality is attributed to a twist of the dca ligands, as discussed above. As shown in b, omitting the hmp– and acetate ligands, the dca ligands are bonded to Cu centers of opposite surfaces of the [Cu4O4] cubane in μ2-1,5 mode, giving rise to an infinite right-handed helical chain. The most intriguing feature is that the right-handed helices are paired and linked via Cu-O coordination, forming a unique double-helical structure. As far as we know, such a 1D chain with DNA-mimic double-helical character is still very rare in systems of metal complexes, and transition-metal complexes with a cubane structure have been extensively explored and exhibit intriguing magnetostructural properties.
elements.clean_text: Both 3a and 3b crystallize in the chiral monoclinic space group P21. The Flack parameters of 0.022(17) (3a) and -0.021(12) (3b) indicate the homochirality of the crystal. Compared with 1 and 2, the asymmetric unit of 3 consists of four Cu(II) ions, two N(CN)2 - anions, four hmp- anions, two CH3COO- anions, and one uncoordinated CH3CN molecule. Compounds 3a and 3b are enantiomers, and only 3a is discussed as examples below. As shown in a, each Cu(II) ion in the asymmetric unit is hexacoordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry. Each CuII is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from one hmp- ligand and one N(CN)2 - anion, three oxygen atoms from three hmp- ligands, and one carboxylate oxygen atom. There are four μ3-O atoms from four hmp- ligands, which connect four Cu cations to form a [Cu4O4] cubane. The chirality is attributed to a twist of the dca ligands, as discussed above. As shown in b, omitting the hmp- and acetate ligands, the dca ligands are bonded to Cu centers of opposite surfaces of the [Cu4O4] cubane in μ2-1,5 mode, giving rise to an infinite right-handed helical chain. The most intriguing feature is that the right-handed helices are paired and linked via Cu-O coordination, forming a unique double-helical structure. As far as we know, such a 1D chain with DNA-mimic double-helical character is still very rare in systems of metal complexes, and transition-metal complexes with a cubane structure have been extensively explored and exhibit intriguing magnetostructural properties.

elements.content: Structure of compound 3a: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) 1D infinite chain and simplified DNA-mimic right-handed double-helical chain.
elements.clean_text: 4  Structure of compound 3a: (a) Representation and numbering scheme of the asymmetric unit. (b) 1D infinite chain and simplified DNA-mimic right-handed double-helical chain.

elements.content: In the absence of any chiral source, the question in molecular design is how to induce chirality into crystal structures from achiral building blocks. With further study into the structures of compounds 1 and 2, it can be found that the solvent used in experiments has an obvious effect on the formation of products with different helices. When water is used as solvent, the CuII ions are coordinated by Hhmp and dca, forming dinuclear copper clusters. The dinuclear copper clusters are further connected by hydrogen bonds between the protonated Hhmp ligands and the additional dca ligands, resulting in the formation of a 1D meso quasi-double-helical chain. Upon changing solvent from H2O (1) to CH3CN/H2O (2), although the Hhmp ligands are still protonated, there are no hydrogen bonds between the Hhmp ligands and the additional dca ligands. The CuII ions are only connected by one dca ligand alternately, giving rise to 1D single helices. However, compound 2 is racemic and no optical activity was observed. Nevertheless, it can be seen from the structures of 1 and 2 that the aromatic ligand Hhmp blocks some coordination sites of the CuII center in a chelating and bidentate fashion and does not serve as a connector between neighboring copper ions as expected, which prevents generating extended networks. Furthermore, obviously, the twisted conformation of the bridging μ2-1,5-dca ligand results in the helicity of the molecular units for compounds 1 and 2. Along these lines, further changing the solvent CH3CN/H2O into CH3CN/CH3OH and using Cu­(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu­(ClO4)2, the Hhmp ligands are deprotonated and the auxiliary ligands CH3COO– block the Cu centers in syn,syn-mode, which favor the generation of the [Cu4O4] cubane units. These [Cu4O4] cubane units of compound 3 are connected alternately by the twisted μ2-1,5-dca ligands, resulting in the formation of extended double-helical chains. Therefore, such an accurate strategy to obtain magnetically ordered helical metal complexes, which utilizes the flexible bridging ligand dca and the chelated aromatic ligand Hhmp, is actually effective.
elements.clean_text: In the absence of any chiral source, the question in molecular design is how to induce chirality into crystal structures from achiral building blocks. With further study into the structures of compounds 1 and 2, it can be found that the solvent used in experiments has an obvious effect on the formation of products with different helices. When water is used as solvent, the CuII ions are coordinated by Hhmp and dca, forming dinuclear copper clusters. The dinuclear copper clusters are further connected by hydrogen bonds between the protonated Hhmp ligands and the additional dca ligands, resulting in the formation of a 1D meso quasi-double-helical chain. Upon changing solvent from H2O (1) to CH3CN/H2O (2), although the Hhmp ligands are still protonated, there are no hydrogen bonds between the Hhmp ligands and the additional dca ligands. The CuII ions are only connected by one dca ligand alternately, giving rise to 1D single helices. However, compound 2 is racemic and no optical activity was observed. Nevertheless, it can be seen from the structures of 1 and 2 that the aromatic ligand Hhmp blocks some coordination sites of the CuII center in a chelating and bidentate fashion and does not serve as a connector between neighboring copper ions as expected, which prevents generating extended networks. Furthermore, obviously, the twisted conformation of the bridging μ2-1,5-dca ligand results in the helicity of the molecular units for compounds 1 and 2. Along these lines, further changing the solvent CH3CN/H2O into CH3CN/CH3OH and using Cu(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu(ClO4)2, the Hhmp ligands are deprotonated and the auxiliary ligands CH3COO- block the Cu centers in syn,syn-mode, which favor the generation of the [Cu4O4] cubane units. These [Cu4O4] cubane units of compound 3 are connected alternately by the twisted μ2-1,5-dca ligands, resulting in the formation of extended double-helical chains. Therefore, such an accurate strategy to obtain magnetically ordered helical metal complexes, which utilizes the flexible bridging ligand dca and the chelated aromatic ligand Hhmp, is actually effective.

elements.content: In order to confirm the homochirality of compounds 3a and 3b, the solid-state CD spectra were measured on crystals with a KBr pellet (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The CD spectrum exhibits strong Cotton effects, indicating that the crystals of 3a and 3b are optically active, respectively. The CD spectra are mirror images, suggesting that 3a and 3b are enantiomers.
elements.clean_text:
CD Spectra

In order to confirm the homochirality of compounds 3a and 3b, the solid-state CD spectra were measured on crystals with a KBr pellet (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The CD spectrum exhibits strong Cotton effects, indicating that the crystals of 3a and 3b are optically active, respectively. The CD spectra are mirror images, suggesting that 3a and 3b are enantiomers.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1–3 were measured on polycrystalline samples in an applied field of 1000 Oe from 2.0 to 300 K. At room temperature, the χm T product is 0.99 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for two spin-only Cu2+ ions (0.75 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 0.87 cm3 K mol–1 at 20 K and then steeply falls down to 0.59 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–50 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.02 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.15 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1-3 were measured on polycrystalline samples in an applied field of 1000 Oe from 2.0 to 300 K. At room temperature, the χm T product is 0.99 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for two spin-only Cu2+ ions (0.75 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 0.87 cm3 K mol-1 at 20 K and then steeply falls down to 0.59 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-50 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.02 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -6.15 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.

elements.content: Plot of χm T vs T for polycrystalline samples of 1 (Inset: χm vs T). The red lines represent the best theoretical fit.
elements.clean_text: 5  Plot of χm T vs T for polycrystalline samples of 1 (Inset: χm vs T). The red lines represent the best theoretical fit.

elements.content: In order to investigate the magnetic coupling in compound 1, a two-spin model was used (Scheme S1), and the corresponding Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian was as follows: H = − 2 J S 1 S 2
elements.clean_text: In order to investigate the magnetic coupling in compound 1, a two-spin model was used (Scheme S1), and the corresponding Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian was as follows: 1    H = - 2 J   S   1     S   2

elements.content: The theoretical expression for the magnetic susceptibility derived from the van Vleck equation is given in the Supporting Information. Least-squares fit of the magnetic data leads to the following results: J = −0.80 cm–1, g = 2.11. The small absolute value of J further confirms the pretty weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.
elements.clean_text: The theoretical expression for the magnetic susceptibility derived from the van Vleck equation is given in the Supporting Information. Least-squares fit of the magnetic data leads to the following results: J = -0.80 cm-1, g = 2.11. The small absolute value of J further confirms the pretty weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.

elements.content: As shown in , the χm T product at room temperature is 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, which is slightly larger than the expected value for one spin-only Cu2+ ion (0.375 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00). Upon cooling, the χm T product is 0.41 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, and it remains almost constant, indicating the paramagnetic behavior of compound 2. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–50 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 0.43 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.17 K.

Upon cooling, the χm T product is 0.41 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, and it remains almost constant, indicating the paramagnetic behavior of compound 2. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-50 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 0.43 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -6.17 K.

elements.content: For 3, the χm T product at room temperature is 1.82 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for four spin-only Cu2+ ions (1.5 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 1.65 cm3 K mol–1 at 75 K and then steeply falls down to 0.17 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–110 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.98 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −11.95 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3.

The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-110 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.98 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -11.95 K. elements.content: It has been found that the dca ligand in its μ-1,5 mode transmits weak interactions between the metals and the J value being only −0.80 cm–1, so the interaction between the Cu4O4 units mediated by the dca ligand in compound 3 can be neglected. A theoretical model for the tetranuclear units was employed to study the magnetic coupling in compound 3. According to our previous report, the magnetic susceptibility data of 3 were fitted by a simplified 3-J model based on the nature of the Cu–O–Cu bonds and angles: (i) exchange interaction J 1 between Cu1 and Cu2 (and Cu3/Cu4), (ii) J 2 between Cu1 and Cu3 (and Cu2/Cu4), (iii) J 3 between Cu1 and Cu4 (and Cu2/Cu3) (Scheme S2). The corresponding Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian was as follows: H = − 2 J 1 ( S 1 S 2 + S 3 S 4 ) − 2 J 2 ( S 1 S 3 + S 2 S 4 ) − 2 J 3 ( S 1 S 4 + S 2 S 3 )
elements.clean_text: It has been found that the dca ligand in its μ-1,5 mode transmits weak interactions between the metals and the J value being only -0.80 cm-1, so the interaction between the Cu4O4 units mediated by the dca ligand in compound 3 can be neglected. A theoretical model for the tetranuclear units was employed to study the magnetic coupling in compound 3. According to our previous report, the magnetic susceptibility data of 3 were fitted by a simplified 3-J model based on the nature of the Cu-O-Cu bonds and angles: (i) exchange interaction J 1 between Cu1 and Cu2 (and Cu3/Cu4), (ii) J 2 between Cu1 and Cu3 (and Cu2/Cu4), (iii) J 3 between Cu1 and Cu4 (and Cu2/Cu3) (Scheme S2). The corresponding Heisenberg spin Hamiltonian was as follows: 2    H = - 2   J   1    (   S   1     S   2   +   S   3     S   4   )  - 2   J   2    (   S   1     S   3   +   S   2     S   4   )  - 2   J   3    (   S   1     S   4   +   S   2     S   3   )

elements.content:
The best fitting results are J 1 = −9.22 cm–1, J 2 = 3.56 cm–1, J 3 = −9.49 cm–1, g = 2.27, which are in agreement with the totally antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3.

Conclusions

In this work, we have successfully developed a promising route to synthesize chiral structured molecular magnets with helical features in the absence of any chiral source: utilizing the flexible bridging ligands and the aromatic ligands, by adjusting the solvent from H2O to CH3CN/H2O and finally CH3CN/CH3OH as well as with Cu­(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu­(ClO4)2 in the buildup of the structures, the helices experienced a successful transformation from mesomeric to racemic, and finally homochiral. Compound 1 exhibits a unique 1D meso quasi-double-helical chain feature, and the left- and right-handed helical chains are coexistent in the single crystal of 2, which is racemic. Compound 3 with a unique DNA-mimic double-helical chain exhibits homochirality in the entire crystal. Such a route may open up new opportunities for preparation of new chiral structured complexes with intriguing magnetostructural properties. In our laboratory, we are currently extending this work to other transition metals to determine the generality of this route or as a specific case here.
elements.clean_text:
The best fitting results are J 1 = -9.22 cm-1, J 2 = 3.56 cm-1, J 3 = -9.49 cm-1, g = 2.27, which are in agreement with the totally antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3.

Conclusions

In this work, we have successfully developed a promising route to synthesize chiral structured molecular magnets with helical features in the absence of any chiral source: utilizing the flexible bridging ligands and the aromatic ligands, by adjusting the solvent from H2O to CH3CN/H2O and finally CH3CN/CH3OH as well as with Cu(CH3COO)2 instead of Cu(ClO4)2 in the buildup of the structures, the helices experienced a successful transformation from mesomeric to racemic, and finally homochiral. Compound 1 exhibits a unique 1D meso quasi-double-helical chain feature, and the left- and right-handed helical chains are coexistent in the single crystal of 2, which is racemic. Compound 3 with a unique DNA-mimic double-helical chain exhibits homochirality in the entire crystal. Such a route may open up new opportunities for preparation of new chiral structured complexes with intriguing magnetostructural properties. In our laboratory, we are currently extending this work to other transition metals to determine the generality of this route or as a specific case here.

cln_elements.content:
All preparations were performed under aerobic conditions; all the reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of Cu­[N­(CN)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(Hhmp) (<bold>1</bold>)

To a stirred solution of Hhmp (0.2181 g, 2 mmol) and triethylamine (2 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added NaC­(CN)2 (0.1781 g, 2 mmol). Then, Cu­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.741 g, 2 mmol) was added to the solution. After stirring for 2 h, the color of the solution changed to blue. The resulting solution was filtered, and the filtrate was then kept at room temperature for slow evaporation. After a few days, blue crystals were obtained. Yield: 75% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7­N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.19; N, 32.26.

Synthesis of {Cu­[N­(CN)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(Hhmp)}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as 1 except for using CH3CN/H2O (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) instead of H2O. Yield: 60% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7­N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.31; H, 2.45; N, 32.03.

Synthesis of {Cu<sub>4</sub>[N­(CN)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>(hmp)<sub>4</sub>­(CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>2</sub>·​CH<sub>3</sub>CN}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 was prepared in the same manner as 2 except that Cu­(CH3COO)2 (0.3992 g, 2 mmol) and CH3CN/CH3OH (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) were used instead of Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O and CH3CN/H2O, respectively. Yield: 50% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C34H33­N11O8Cu4 (977.91): C, 41.76; H, 3.40; N, 15.76. Found: C, 41.85; H, 3.33; N, 15.65.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Syntheses

All preparations were performed under aerobic conditions; all the reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification.

Synthesis of Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp) (1)

To a stirred solution of Hhmp (0.2181 g, 2 mmol) and triethylamine (2 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added NaC(CN)2 (0.1781 g, 2 mmol). Then, Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.741 g, 2 mmol) was added to the solution. After stirring for 2 h, the color of the solution changed to blue. The resulting solution was filtered, and the filtrate was then kept at room temperature for slow evaporation. After a few days, blue crystals were obtained. Yield: 75% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.52; H, 2.19; N, 32.26.

Synthesis of {Cu[N(CN)2]2(Hhmp)}∞ (2)

Complex 2 was prepared in the same manner as 1 except for using CH3CN/H2O (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) instead of H2O. Yield: 60% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C10H7N7OCu (304.78): C, 39.41; H, 2.31; N, 32.17. Found: C, 39.31; H, 2.45; N, 32.03.

Synthesis of {Cu4[N(CN)2]2(hmp)4(CH3COO)2⋅CH3CN}∞ (3)

Complex 3 was prepared in the same manner as 2 except that Cu(CH3COO)2 (0.3992 g, 2 mmol) and CH3CN/CH3OH (20 mL, 10:1, v/v) were used instead of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and CH3CN/H2O, respectively. Yield: 50% (based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C34H33N11O8Cu4 (977.91): C, 41.76; H, 3.40; N, 15.76. Found: C, 41.85; H, 3.33; N, 15.65.

cln_elements.content:
The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1–3 were measured on polycrystalline samples in an applied field of 1000 Oe from 2.0 to 300 K. At room temperature, the χm T product is 0.99 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for two spin-only Cu2+ ions (0.75 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 0.87 cm3 K mol–1 at 20 K and then steeply falls down to 0.59 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–50 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.02 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.15 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.

As shown in , the χm T product at room temperature is 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, which is slightly larger than the expected value for one spin-only Cu2+ ion (0.375 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00). Upon cooling, the χm T product is 0.41 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, and it remains almost constant, indicating the paramagnetic behavior of compound 2. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–50 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 0.43 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −6.17 K.

For 3, the χm T product at room temperature is 1.82 cm3 K mol–1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for four spin-only Cu2+ ions (1.5 cm3 K mol–1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 1.65 cm3 K mol–1 at 75 K and then steeply falls down to 0.17 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300–110 K were fitted according to Curie–Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.98 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −11.95 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities of 1-3 were measured on polycrystalline samples in an applied field of 1000 Oe from 2.0 to 300 K. At room temperature, the χm T product is 0.99 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for two spin-only Cu2+ ions (0.75 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 0.87 cm3 K mol-1 at 20 K and then steeply falls down to 0.59 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-50 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.02 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -6.15 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 1.

As shown in , the χm T product at room temperature is 0.45 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, which is slightly larger than the expected value for one spin-only Cu2+ ion (0.375 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.00). Upon cooling, the χm T product is 0.41 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, and it remains almost constant, indicating the paramagnetic behavior of compound 2. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-50 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 0.43 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -6.17 K.

For 3, the χm T product at room temperature is 1.82 cm3 K mol-1, which is slightly larger than the expected value for four spin-only Cu2+ ions (1.5 cm3 K mol-1, g = 2.00; see in ). Upon cooling, the χm T product slowly decreases to 1.65 cm3 K mol-1 at 75 K and then steeply falls down to 0.17 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, indicating the existence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3. The experimental data for χm vs T between 300-110 K were fitted according to Curie-Weiss law, and the fitting results are C = 1.98 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -11.95 K. The negative Weiss constant also indicates the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions in compound 3.

metadata.title:
An Efficient Strategy for Self-Assembly of DNA-Mimic
Homochiral 1D Helical Cu(II) Chain from Achiral Flexible Ligand by
Spontaneous Resolution
